articles.title: The DRC’s Kivu-Kinshasa Green Corridor aims to create a new green economy for peace and sustainable development
articles.summary: Officials say the corridor will create hundreds of thousands of jobs, thereby providing more economic options so people are not pressured to join armed groups due to poverty.
articles.content:
This article by Anicet Kimonyo was originally published by Peace News Network on October 29, 2025. An edited version is republished on Global Voices as part of a media partnership agreement.

Armed conflicts in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) are fueling poverty and accelerating environmental degradation.

In North Kivu province, home to Virunga National Park, one of the oldest in Africa, nearly 50 percent of the park’s territory is now under the control of armed groups, according to an assessment by the Provincial Directorate of North Kivu of the Congolese Institute for the Conservation of Nature (ICCN) from April 2025. These groups include the Alliance Fleuve Congo (AFC)-M23 rebels, Islamist groups, and various smaller local militias, as well as Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), which has members who took part in the Rwanda Genocide in 1994.

This armed presence around the park deprives the green economy of an estimated USD 30 million a year in revenue, diverted to rebel groups, according to the report. This perpetuates a cycle of violence to the detriment of biodiversity and local development.

The DRC has officially launched, by decree, the “Kivu-Kinshasa Green Corridor” (CVKK), a colossal project that aims to combine reforestation, economic development, and the stabilization of conflict-ravaged regions. The initiative, presented by authorities as a major contribution to the fight against climate change, will nevertheless require the government to overcome numerous structural and political challenges.

Signed on January 15, 2025, by Prime Minister Judith Suminwa, Decree No. 25/01 gives substance to one of the largest greening initiatives ever conceived in Central Africa. Spanning nearly 550,000 square kilometers, including 285,000 square kilometers of primary forests and 60,000 square kilometers of peatlands, the CVKK aims to transform areas weakened by decades of violence into hubs of sustainable growth. Emmanuel de Mérode, director of the ICCN, says:

The CVKK project is considered one of the largest initiatives [in the world] on the climate issue. The Congo is providing good news, and this will continue to be noticed.

In addition to protecting the Congo Basin, described as “the world’s largest tropical forest carbon sink,” the corridor is expected to enable the annual transfer of 1 million tons of food from the Kivus to Kinshasa. This will help to feed people impacted by conflict, primarily, and the entire country, considering the agricultural potential of this Green Corridor area. A dedicated fund will be created to develop businesses along the route in renewable energy, agriculture, and logistics. The government estimates the project will require at least USD 1 billion in financing over the next three to four years.

The CVKK is structured around several pillars: sustainable agriculture, ecotourism, community forestry, and ecosystem restoration. The stated objective is to create hundreds of thousands of “green” jobs, thereby providing legal alternatives to poaching and illegal resource exploitation. Emmanuel de Mérode explains:

The corridor provides economic benefits that do not depend on forest destruction, but on sustainable production methods. Hundreds of thousands of jobs [will be] created thanks to the preservation of species and forests. The communities themselves become conservation agents.

In Bas-Uélé, forest administrator Justin Tshipopo welcomes an “opportunity to strengthen community forestry.” He emphasizes the need to take traditional knowledge into account. He said:

Communities have preserved their forests for centuries. These practices must not be forgotten.

He stresses that the corridor must become a concrete instrument of development in fragile territories, capable of generating economic opportunities and strengthening social cohesion.

Long-term success will depend on the authorities’ ability to sustainably involve local populations, integrate their ancestral knowledge, and ensure impeccable governance. The Kivu-Kinshasa Green Corridor thus presents itself as a crucial test for the DRC’s ecological and economic transition, a challenge worthy of its immense natural resources.

While the ambitions are lauded, local activists are also demanding inclusive and transparent implementation. Fanny Minesi, representing the wildlife conservation NGO Friends of Bonobos of Congo (ABC), warns against a purely technocratic approach to the project. She asserts:

Our concern is to ensure that communities are not only informed, but also that they consent to the projects and become active participants. We must ensure that projects are not designed without the communities, and that the private sector, often preoccupied with profit, is not the only one guiding the decisions.

The success of the CVKK depends on close coordination between the government, conservation agencies, the private sector, and communities. However, land tensions, weak infrastructure, and historical mistrust persist. Some local populations are wary of the project, as they believe the government wants to take their land.

Pilot initiatives in the eastern DRC and Tshopo, however, are showing encouraging results, with a measurable reduction in local violence by armed groups against civilians and improved protection of Virunga National Park. Officials say the corridor will create jobs for hundreds of thousands of people, including young people, and will help them access more economic options so they are not pressured to join armed groups due to poverty.

Already, the DRC launched Climate Week on Monday, October 27, with the aim of bringing together stakeholders in the climate sector to jointly reflect on the issues. The Congolese Minister of the Environment and Climate Economy, Marie Nyange Ndambo, said during a press conference:

Without the DRC, there are no sustainable solutions to the global climate crisis, which we have not created elsewhere.

Continuing her address to the participants of the Congolese National Climate Week, Ndambo clarified that through the Congolese National Climate Week, the DRC aims to unite the voices of civil society, indigenous peoples, and other local and national stakeholders to prepare for COP30, which will be held in Belem, Brazil, starting November 1o, with a strong and credible conviction that “reflects our priorities and realities, so that at Belem, the Congo and the Congolese people speak with one voice and affirm that the DRC is ready to assume its role as a climate leader.” Nyange added
articles.reasoning: The article describes the launch of the Kivu-Kinshasa Green Corridor in the DRC, a large-scale initiative combining reforestation, sustainable economic development, and conflict stabilization. It aims to create hundreds of thousands of green jobs, protect one of the world's largest tropical forest carbon sinks, and reduce violence by providing economic alternatives to armed groups. The project has broad significance for climate action, biodiversity conservation, and social stability in a conflict-affected region, with detailed context and clear positive impact.
articles.personality_title: DRC launches Kivu-Kinshasa Green Corridor to boost jobs and protect forests
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The eastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) faces armed conflicts that harm both people and the environment. In North Kivu province, many areas of Virunga National Park are controlled by armed groups, hurting the local economy and nature.

This project covers nearly 550,000 square kilometers, including forests and peatlands. It aims to restore damaged lands, support farming, and create jobs that depend on protecting nature instead of harming it.

articles.title: Flexible perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells with 33.6% efficiency
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09849-4Flexible perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells with 33.6% efficiency
articles.content: Flexible solar cells have a transformative potential for niche applications, yet face fundamental challenges in simultaneously achieving high power conversion efficiency (PCE), extreme mechanical resilience and operational stability1–4. Herein, we demonstrate a certified 33.6%-efficient flexible perovskite/crystalline silicon (c-Si) tandem solar cell with a record open-circuit voltage (V oc ) of 2.015 V, rivaling its rigid counterpart. The flexible tandem retains 91% of its initial PCE after 5,000 cycles under a bending radius (R b ) of 17.6 mm, and demonstrates exceptional operational and damp-heat (DH) stability, featuring a T 80 lifetime exceeding 2,000 hours under continuous illumination and retaining 90% of its initial PCE after 1,000 hours DH test. This advancement is enabled by implementation of the reactive-plasma-deposited (RPD) cerium and hydrogen co-doped indium oxide (ICO:H) recombination layer (RL) that promotes self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) coverage and interfacial charge transfer, and in-situ annealed zinc-doped indium oxide (IZO) front transparent electrode with significantly enhanced optoelectronic and mechanical properties.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant technological breakthrough in flexible perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells achieving a record high efficiency of 33.6%, combined with exceptional mechanical resilience and operational stability. This advancement has broad implications for renewable energy technology, potentially enabling more versatile and durable solar power solutions that can accelerate clean energy adoption and reduce carbon emissions globally.
articles.personality_title: New flexible solar cells reach record 33.6% efficiency with strong durability
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Solar cells convert sunlight into electricity. Traditional solar panels are rigid, which limits where they can be used. Flexible solar cells could be attached to curved surfaces or portable devices, but they usually don’t work as well or last as long.

**What happened** – Scientists have created a new type of flexible solar cell made by combining two materials: perovskite and silicon. These solar cells reached a certified efficiency of 33.6%, meaning they convert over one-third of sunlight into electricity. They also stay strong after bending many times and keep working well even after long exposure to heat and moisture.

**Impact** – This is the highest efficiency reported for flexible solar cells so far. The cells kept 91% of their power after being bent 5,000 times and remained stable during tough conditions. This shows flexible solar panels can be both powerful and durable, which is important for using solar energy in new ways, like on curved roofs, vehicles, or wearable devices.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely work on making these solar cells easier and cheaper to produce. They may also test them in real-world settings to see how they perform outside the lab. If successful, this technology could lead to more flexible and efficient solar energy products in the market.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists developed highly efficient and durable flexible solar cells that could expand where and how solar power is used.

articles.title: Witnessing chamois populations recover
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03640-1Haritakis Papaioannou combines a mountaineer’s know-how with a scientific eye to track the slow recovery of chamois populations in western Greece.
articles.content:
“The first time I saw a chamois, a mammal closely related to both goats and antelopes, was more than 40 years ago while I was hiking in Epirus, a mountainous region in western Greece. Chamois were rare then; the desire to learn about and protect them inspired me to become a biologist. Over the past 25 years, their population in my study area — the Northern Pindos National Park — has grown drastically, mainly thanks to a ‘human shield’ effect created by hikers visiting the upper parts of the Northern Pindos mountain range: their presence has made poaching more difficult.

Now, I can easily see dozens of Balkan chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra balcanica) just a few hours from my village. In this picture, I’m counting them on the ledges of a cliff, one of their favourite habitats. We think that there are now around 1,000 individuals in the national park and nearby mountain ranges.

Studying chamois requires the skills of a mountaineer and a scientist’s precision. My colleagues and I have built a habitat suitability model, based on elevation, vegetation, slope and human activity, and are testing it by checking for chamois presence in areas across northern and central Greece. We have discovered small populations in those areas and are in the process of defining wildlife corridors and identifying threats to those populations.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the significant recovery of chamois populations in western Greece due to conservation effects linked to human presence deterring poaching. It highlights a meaningful positive impact on wildlife conservation with broad ecological significance and provides detailed scientific efforts to monitor and support the species, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Chamois populations recover in Greece’s mountains thanks to hikers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Chamois are wild animals related to goats and antelopes that live in mountainous areas. In western Greece, their numbers had dropped and they were rare because of hunting.

**What happened** – Over the past 25 years, the number of chamois in Northern Pindos National Park has grown a lot. This is mainly because hikers visiting the mountains made it harder for hunters to catch the animals. Now, about 1,000 chamois live in this park and nearby areas.

**Impact** – This recovery shows how people enjoying nature can help protect wildlife. The presence of hikers acts like a “human shield” that keeps poachers away. Scientists are also studying where chamois live by using maps of the land and checking different areas, which helps protect the animals better.

**What's next step** – Researchers are working to connect different chamois groups by creating wildlife corridors, which are safe paths for animals to move between habitats. They are also looking for new threats to keep the populations healthy.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The return of chamois in Greece’s mountains shows how careful human activity and science can help endangered animals come back.

articles.personality_title_es: Las poblaciones de rebecos se recuperan en las montañas de Grecia gracias a los excursionistas
articles.personality_presentation_es:

articles.title: The first glass recycling line is presented in Albania, with the support of the EU4CELC program
articles.summary: Built by Albanian engineers, the line processes up to 36,000 tons/year, creating partnerships with manufacturers, distributors, and HORECA businesses to turn glass from landfill into a source of value.
articles.content:
Built by Albanian engineers, the line processes up to 36,000 tons/year, creating partnerships with manufacturers, distributors, and HORECA businesses to turn glass from landfill into a source of value.

In Albania, the first glass recycling line was presented, which represents a significant step towards the sustainable management of approximately 42,000 tons of glass waste per year.

“Albania Glass Recycling” in Bubq, Krujë is the first glass recycling company in Albania, which represents a new step towards a circular economy.

The recycling line was realized thanks to the support of the European Union through the EU4CELC program, with the support of GIZ Albania and BMZ, RecycAl – Circular Economy Park.

Built by Albanian engineers, the line processes up to 36,000 tons/year, creating partnerships with manufacturers, distributors, and HORECA businesses to turn glass from landfill into a source of value.

This process will yield two sustainable products: VetroPool – recycled glass sand for water filtration in swimming pools; Terrazo glass – decorative material for tiles, interior design, and urban furniture.

The European Union delegation in Tirana notes that this is a concrete example of the circular economy in action and of the EU-Albania partnership for a greener future.

At the presentation of this first initiative of its kind in Albania, the Albanian Minister of Environment, Sofjan Jaupaj, was also present, who described this company as a clear example of cooperation between the government, the private sector, and international partners.

“This company will bring concrete results for a greener economy and by reducing the volume of waste. During this month, we have had a series of inaugurations in other cities regarding waste collection and recycling stations, where a good portion of waste is recycled and returned to the market, thus reducing the amount of waste in the country’s territory, as well as the waste that ends up in landfills,” emphasized Jaupaj.

According to Minister Jaupaj, the approval in the Assembly of the new law “On waste management” brings a new approach, but also conforms to EU legislation, where collection and recycling are at its core.

Currently, recycling rates are still at 18%. The Albanian market, with 870,000 tons of waste produced annually, is an important market for recyclers.

Albania has opened 5 out of 6 negotiation chapters with the European Union and expects to open the last one within the year, where the environment and food safety chapter remains among the most important. (November 10)
articles.reasoning: The article reports the inauguration of Albania's first glass recycling line, a significant environmental advancement with broad impact on waste management and circular economy in the country. It highlights tangible benefits such as processing large volumes of glass waste, creating sustainable products, and fostering partnerships across sectors, supported by EU collaboration. The story is focused, detailed, and demonstrates a meaningful step toward sustainability and EU-aligned environmental policy.
articles.personality_title: Albania launches its first glass recycling line to turn waste into useful products
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Albania produces about 42,000 tons of glass waste every year, but until now, it had no dedicated facility to recycle this glass and give it a new life. Recycling is important for reducing waste and protecting the environment.

**What happened** – A new glass recycling line was opened in Bubq, Krujë, built by Albanian engineers with support from the European Union and other partners. This facility can process up to 36,000 tons of glass each year. It works by collecting glass from manufacturers, distributors, and businesses like hotels and restaurants, and turning it into new materials.

**Impact** – This recycling line creates two useful products: recycled glass sand for cleaning swimming pools and decorative glass materials used in tiles and furniture. It helps reduce the amount of glass going to landfills and supports Albania’s goal to recycle more waste. The project also shows how the government, private companies, and international groups can work together for a cleaner environment.

**What's next step** – Albania plans to improve its waste management laws and open more recycling stations. The country is also moving closer to joining the European Union, where environmental protection is a key part of the agreement. This recycling line could inspire more projects to handle different types of waste sustainably.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Albania’s new glass recycling line turns thousands of tons of waste into valuable products, marking a big step toward better recycling and environmental care in the country.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'Albanie inaugure sa première ligne de recyclage du verre pour transformer les déchets en produits utiles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Albanie produit environ 42 000 tonnes de déchets de verre chaque année, mais jusqu'à présent, elle ne disposait d'aucune installation dédiée pour recycler ce verre et lui donner une nouvelle vie. Le recyclage est important pour réduire les déchets et protéger l'environnement.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une nouvelle ligne de recyclage du verre a été ouverte à Bubq, Krujë, construite par des ingénieurs albanais avec le soutien de l'Union européenne et d'autres partenaires. Cette installation peut traiter jusqu'à 36 000 tonnes de verre par an. Elle collecte le verre auprès des fabricants, distributeurs et entreprises comme les hôtels et restaurants, puis le transforme en nouveaux matériaux.

**Impact** – Cette ligne de recyclage crée deux produits utiles : du sable de verre recyclé pour le nettoyage des piscines et des matériaux décoratifs en verre utilisés dans les carreaux et le mobilier. Elle aide à réduire la quantité de verre envoyée en décharge et soutient l'objectif de l'Albanie d'augmenter le recyclage des déchets. Ce projet montre aussi comment le gouvernement, les entreprises privées et les groupes internationaux peuvent collaborer pour un environnement plus propre.

**Prochaines étapes** – L'Albanie prévoit d'améliorer ses lois sur la gestion des déchets et d'ouvrir davantage de stations de recyclage. Le pays se rapproche aussi de l'Union européenne, où la protection de l'environnement est un point clé de l'accord. Cette ligne de recyclage pourrait inspirer d'autres projets pour gérer durablement différents types de déchets.

**Phrase clé** – La nouvelle ligne de recyclage du verre en Albanie transforme des milliers de tonnes de déchets en produits précieux, marquant une avancée importante vers un meilleur recyclage et une meilleure protection de l'environnement dans le pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Albania inaugura su primera línea de reciclaje de vidrio para convertir residuos en productos útiles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Albania produce alrededor de 42,000 toneladas de residuos de vidrio cada año, pero hasta ahora no tenía una planta dedicada para reciclar este vidrio y darle una nueva vida. El reciclaje es importante para reducir los residuos y proteger el medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó** – Se abrió una nueva línea de reciclaje de vidrio en Bubq, Krujë, construida por ingenieros albaneses con el apoyo de la Unión Europea y otros socios. Esta planta puede procesar hasta 36,000 toneladas de vidrio al año. Recoge vidrio de fabricantes, distribuidores y negocios como hoteles y restaurantes, y lo convierte en nuevos materiales.

**Impacto** – Esta línea de reciclaje crea dos productos útiles: arena de vidrio reciclada para limpiar piscinas y materiales decorativos de vidrio usados en azulejos y muebles. Ayuda a reducir la cantidad de vidrio que va a los vertederos y apoya la meta de Albania de reciclar más residuos. El proyecto también muestra cómo el gobierno, las empresas y grupos internacionales pueden trabajar juntos por un ambiente más limpio.

**Próximo paso** – Albania planea mejorar sus leyes de gestión de residuos y abrir más estaciones de reciclaje. El país también está avanzando hacia su ingreso a la Unión Europea, donde la protección ambiental es clave. Esta línea de reciclaje podría inspirar más proyectos para manejar diferentes tipos de residuos de forma sostenible.

**Frase clave** – La nueva línea de reciclaje de vidrio en Albania convierte miles de toneladas de residuos en productos valiosos, marcando un gran avance hacia un mejor reciclaje y cuidado ambiental en el país.
